tf.q: A general-purpose computer is designed to perform one specific task only.
tf.correction: It is designed to perform many different tasks.

tf.q: Response time is always a critical factor in general-purpose computing systems.
tf.correction: Response time is critical in real-time embedded systems, not necessarily in general-purpose systems.

tf.q: Applications in an embedded system are typically alterable by the end-user.
tf.correction: Applications are typically non-alterable by the user.

tf.q: A System on Chip (SoC) is generally smaller and consumes less power than a System Board (SB).
A System Board (SB) is 'configurable', meaning it is easier to edit during the design phase.
A Microprocessor Unit (MPU) is a complete computing system on a single chip.
tf.correction: This describes a Microcontroller (MCU). An MPU is just the processor itself without memory or I/O on the same chip.

tf.q: A Microcontroller Unit (MCU) contains an MPU, memory, and I/O components.
VLSI stands for Very Large-Scale Integrated Circuit.
A single computing system can have multiple CPUs (Central Processing Units).
tf.correction: A system has one primary CPU, but can have multiple other processors (like GPUs, DSPs).

tf.q: A DSP (Digital Signal Processor) is a microprocessor specialized for graphics operations.
tf.correction: That describes a GPU. A DSP is specialized for complex mathematical computations, particularly for signal processing.
